column1: Neonatal conjunctivitis is swelling (inflammation) or infection of the tissue lining the eyelids in a newborn.
A mild form of neonatal conjunctivitis can be caused by bacteria that normally live in a woman's vagina.
Infection caused by other bacteria or viruses can be very serious.
Herpes eye infections are less common than those caused by gonorrhea and chlamydia.
The mother may not have symptoms at the time of delivery.
The health care provider will perform an eye exam on the baby.
Antibiotics are often needed for eye infections caused by bacteria.
Special antiviral eye drops or ointments are used for herpes infections of the eye.
- Blindness - Inflammation of the iris - Scar or hole in the cornea--the clear structure that is over the colored part of the eye (the iris)
